I'll be nice wi' a wench as long as niceness be the key to her favour. But sink me now if I'd rot myself in rum on account of anything that wears a petticoat.

column2: That's not the Old Wolf's way.
column3: That's not the Old Wolf's way.

column2: If there's no other expedition'll tempt you, why not Port Royal?
column3: If there's no other expedition'll tempt you, why not Port Royal?

column2: What a plague do it matter if it is an English settlement?
column3: What a plague do it matter if it is an English settlement?

column2: It's commanded by Colonel Bishop, and there's no lack of rascals in your company'd follow you to hell if it meant getting Colonel Bishop by the throat.
column3: It's commanded by Colonel Bishop, and there's no lack of rascals in your company'd follow you to hell if it meant getting Colonel Bishop by the throat.

column2: It could be done, I tell you.
column3: It could be done, I tell you.

column2: We've but to spy the chance when the Jamaica fleet is away.
column3: We've but to spy the chance when the Jamaica fleet is away.

column2: There's enough plunder in the town to tempt the lads, and there's the wench for you.
column3: There's enough plunder in the town to tempt the lads, and there's the wench for you.

column2: Shall I sound them on 't?"
column3: Shall I sound them on 't?"

column2: Blood was on his feet, his eyes blazing, his livid face distorted. "Ye'll leave my cabin this minute, so ye will, or, by Heaven, it's your corpse'll be carried out of it.
column3: Blood was on his feet, his eyes blazing, his livid face distorted. "Ye'll leave my cabin this minute, so ye will, or, by Heaven, it's your corpse'll be carried out of it.

column2: Ye mangy hound, d'ye dare come to me with such proposals?"
column3: Ye mangy hound, d'ye dare come to me with such proposals?"

column2: He fell to cursing his faithful officer with a virulence the like of which he had never yet been known to use.
column3: He fell to cursing his faithful officer with a virulence the like of which he had never yet been known to use.

column2: And Wolverstone, in terror before that fury, went out without another word.
column3: And Wolverstone, in terror before that fury, went out without another word.

column2: The subject was not raised again, and Captain Blood was left to his idle abstraction.
column3: The subject was not raised again, and Captain Blood was left to his idle abstraction.

column2: But at last, as his buccaneers were growing desperate, something happened, brought about by the Captain's friend M. d'Ogeron.
column3: But at last, as his buccaneers were growing desperate, something happened, brought about by the Captain's friend m d'Ogeron.

column2: One sunny morning the Governor of Tortuga came aboard the Arabella, accompanied by a chubby little gentleman, amiable of countenance, amiable and self-sufficient of manner.
column3: One sunny morning the Governor of Tortuga came aboard the Arabella, accompanied by a chubby little gentleman, amiable of countenance, amiable and self-sufficient of manner.

column2: My Captain, M. d'Ogeron delivered himself, "I bring you M. de Cussy, the Governor of French Hispaniola, who desires a word with you."
column3: My Captain, m d'Ogeron delivered himself, "I bring you m de Cussy, the Governor of French Hispaniola, who desires a word with you."

column2: Out of consideration for his friend, Captain Blood pulled the pipe from his mouth, shook some of the rum out of his wits, and rose and made a leg to M. de Cussy.
column3: Out of consideration for his friend, Captain Blood pulled the pipe from his mouth, shook some of the rum out of his wits, and rose and made a leg to m de Cussy.

column2: Serviteur! said he.
column3: Serviteur! said he.

column2: M. de Cussy returned the bow and accepted a seat on the locker under the stem windows.
column3: M. de Cussy returned the bow and accepted a seat on the locker under the stem windows.

column2: You have a good force here under your command, my Captain, said he.
column3: You have a good force here under your command, my Captain, said he.

column2: Some eight hundred men.
column3: Some eight hundred men.

column2: And I understand they grow restive in idleness.
column3: And I understand they grow restive in idleness.

column2: They may go to the devil when they please.
column3: They may go to the devil when they please.

column2: M. de Cussy took snuff delicately.
column3: M. de Cussy took snuff delicately.

column2: I have something better than that to propose, said he.
column3: I have something better than that to propose, said he.

column2: Propose it, then, said Blood, without interest.
column3: Propose it, then, said Blood, without interest.

column2: M. de Cussy looked at M. d'Ogeron, and raised his eyebrows a little. He did not find Captain Blood encouraging.
column3: M. de Cussy looked at m d'Ogeron, and raised his eyebrows a little. He did not find Captain Blood encouraging.

column2: But M. d'Ogeron nodded vigorously with pursed lips, and the Governor of Hispaniola propounded his business.
column3: But m d'Ogeron nodded vigorously with pursed lips, and the Governor of Hispaniola propounded his business.

column2: News has reached us from France that there is war with Spain.
column3: News has reached us from France that there is war with Spain.

column2: That is news, is it? growled Blood.
column3: That is news, is it? growled Blood.

column2: I am speaking officially, my Captain.	I am speaking officially, my Captain.
column3: true

column2: I am not alluding to unofficial skirmishes, and unofficial predatory measures which we have condoned out here.
column3: I am not alluding to unofficial skirmishes, and unofficial predatory measures which we have condoned out here.

column2: There is war--formally war--between France and Spain in Europe.
column3: There is war-formally war-between France and Spain in Europe.

column2: It is the intention of France that this war shall be carried into the New World.
column3: It is the intention of France that this war shall be carried into the New World.

column2: A fleet is coming out from Brest under the command of M. le Baron de Rivarol for that purpose.
column3: A fleet is coming out from Brest under the command of m le Baron de Rivarol for that purpose.

column2: I have letters from him desiring me to equip a supplementary squadron and raise a body of not less than a thousand men to reenforce him on his arrival.
column3: I have letters from him desiring me to equip a supplementary squadron and raise a body of not less than a thousand men to reenforce him on his arrival.

column2: What I have come to propose to you, my Captain, at the suggestion of our good friend M. d'Ogeron, is, in brief, that you enroll your ships and your force under M. de Rivarol's flag."
column3: What I have come to propose to you, my Captain, at the suggestion of our good friend m d'Ogeron, is, in brief, that you enroll your ships and your force under m de Rivarol's flag."

column2: Blood looked at him with a faint kindling of interest.
column3: Blood looked at him with a faint kindling of interest.

column2: You are offering to take us into the French service? he asked.
column3: You are offering to take us into the French service? he asked.

column2: On what terms, monsieur?
column3: On what terms, monsieur?

column2: With the rank of Capitaine de Vaisseau for yourself, and suitable ranks for the officers serving under you.	With the rank of Capitaine de Vaisseau for yourself, and suitable ranks for the officers serving under you.
column3: true

column2: You will enjoy the pay of that rank, and you will be entitled, together with your men, to one-tenth share in all prizes taken."
column3: You will enjoy the pay of that rank, and you will be entitled, together with your men, to one tenth share in all prizes taken."

column2: My men will hardly account it generous.	My men will hardly account it generous.
column3: true

column2: They will tell you that they can sail out of here to-morrow, disembowel a Spanish settlement, and keep the whole of the plunder."
column3: They will tell you that they can sail out of here to morrow, disembowel a Spanish settlement, and keep the whole of the plunder."

column2: Ah, yes, but with the risks attaching to acts of piracy.	Ah, yes, but with the risks attaching to acts of piracy.
column3: false

column2: With us your position will be regular and official, and considering the powerful fleet by which M. de Rivarol is backed, the enterprises to be undertaken will be on a much vaster scale than anything you could attempt on your own account.
column3: With us your position will be regular and official, and considering the powerful fleet by which m de Rivarol is backed, the enterprises to be undertaken will be on a much vaster scale than anything you could attempt on your own account.

column2: So that the one tenth in this case may be equal to more than the whole in the other."
column3: So that the one tenth in this case may be equal to more than the whole in the other."

column2: Captain Blood considered.
column3: Captain Blood considered.

column2: This, after all, was not piracy that was being proposed.
column3: This, after all, was not piracy that was being proposed.

column2: It was honourable employment in the service of the King of France.
column3: It was honourable employment in the service of the King of France.

column2: I will consult my officers, he said; and he sent for them.
column3: I will consult my officers, he said; and he sent for them.

column2: They came and the matter was laid before them by M. de Cussy himself. Hagthorpe announced at once that the proposal was opportune.
column3: They came and the matter was laid before them by m de Cussy himself. Hagthorpe announced at once that the proposal was opportune.

column2: The men were grumbling at their protracted inaction, and would no doubt be ready to accept the service which M. de Cussy offered on behalf of France. Hagthorpe looked at Blood as he spoke.
column3: The men were grumbling at their protracted inaction, and would no doubt be ready to accept the service which m de Cussy offered on behalf of France. Hagthorpe looked at Blood as he spoke.

column2: Blood nodded gloomy agreement. Emboldened by this, they went on to discuss the terms.
column3: Blood nodded gloomy agreement. Emboldened by this, they went on to discuss the terms.

column2: Yberville, the young French filibuster, had the honour to point out to M. de Cussy that the share offered was too small.
column3: Yberville, the young French filibuster, had the honour to point out to m de Cussy that the share offered was too small.

column2: For one fifth of the prizes, the officers would answer for their men; not for less.
column3: For one fifth of the prizes, the officers would answer for their men; not for less.

column2: M. de Cussy was distressed.
column3: M. de Cussy was distressed.

column2: He had his instructions.
column3: He had his instructions.

column2: It was taking a deal upon himself to exceed them.
column3: It was taking a deal upon himself to exceed them.

column2: The buccaneers were firm.
column3: The buccaneers were firm.

column2: Unless M. de Cussy could make it one fifth there was no more to be said.
column3: Unless m de Cussy could make it one fifth there was no more to be said.

column2: M. de Cussy finally consenting to exceed his instructions, the articles were drawn up and signed that very day.
column3: M. de Cussy finally consenting to exceed his instructions, the articles were drawn up and signed that very day.

column2: The buccaneers were to be at Petit Goave by the end of January, when M. de Rivarol had announced that he might be expected.
column3: The buccaneers were to be at Petit Goave by the end of January, when m de Rivarol had announced that he might be expected.

column2: After that followed days of activity in Tortuga, refitting the ships, boucanning meat, laying in stores.
column3: After that followed days of activity in Tortuga, refitting the ships, boucanning meat, laying in stores.

column2: In these matters which once would have engaged all Captain Blood's attention, he now took no part. He continued listless and aloof.
column3: In these matters which once would have engaged all Captain Blood's attention, he now took no part. He continued listless and aloof.

column2: If he had given his consent to the undertaking, or, rather, allowed himself to be swept into it by the wishes of his officers--it was only because the service offered was of a regular and honourable kind, nowise connected with piracy, with which he swore in his heart that he had done for ever.
column3: If he had given his consent to the undertaking, or, rather, allowed himself to be swept into it by the wishes of his officers-it was only because the service offered was of a regular and honourable kind, nowise connected with piracy, with which he swore in his heart that he had done for ever.

column2: But his consent remained passive.
column3: But his consent remained passive.

column2: The service entered awoke no zeal in him.
column3: The service entered awoke no zeal in him.

column2: He was perfectly indifferent--as he told Hagthorpe, who ventured once to offer a remonstrance--whether they went to Petit Goave or to Hades, and whether they entered the service of Louis XIV or of Satan.
column3: He was perfectly indifferent-as he told Hagthorpe, who ventured once to offer a remonstrance-whether they went to Petit Goave or to Hades, and whether they entered the service of Louis the fourteenth or of Satan.
